Abstract

We ask the question, which oriented trees Tğ‘‡Titalic_T must be contained as subgraphs in every finite directed graph of sufficiently large minimum out-degree. We formulate the following simple condition: all vertices in Tğ‘‡Titalic_T of in-degree at least 2222 must be on the same â€˜levelâ€™ in the natural height function of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. We prove this condition to be necessary and conjecture it to be sufficient. In support of our conjecture, we prove it for a fairly general class of trees.

An essential tool in the latter proof, and a question interesting in its own right, is finding large subdivided in-stars in a directed graph of large minimum out-degree. We conjecture that any digraph and oriented graph of minimum out-degree at least kâ¢â„“ğ‘˜â„“k\ellitalic_k roman_â„“ and kâ¢â„“/2ğ‘˜â„“2k\ell/2italic_k roman_â„“ / 2, respectively, contains the (kâˆ’1)ğ‘˜1(k-1)( italic_k - 1 )-subdivision of the in-star with â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ leaves as a subgraph; this would be tight and generalizes a conjecture of ThomassÃ©. We prove this for digraphs and k=2ğ‘˜2k=2italic_k = 2 up to a factor of less than 4444.

The rest of the paper is structured as follows. In Section 2 we provide a construction proving Theorem 1.3. Section 3 contains the proof of our main result, Theorem 1.5. Finally, in Section 4 we prove Theorem 1.8.

A directed path is an orientation of an undirected path which can be traversed from one end to the other following the orientations of the edges. A subdivision of a digraph GğºGitalic_G introduces some new vertices on the edges of GğºGitalic_G and replaces the edges with directed paths, inheriting the directions. A kğ‘˜kitalic_k-subdivision is the subdivision with kğ‘˜kitalic_k new vertices for each edge. An oriented tree is an orientation of an undirected tree. An in-arborescence/out-arborescence is an oriented tree in which all edges are oriented towards/away from a designated root vertex. By Bk,â„“+subscriptsuperscriptğµğ‘˜â„“B^{+}_{k,\ell}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we denote the â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“-branching out-arborescence of depth kğ‘˜kitalic_k, i.e. the complete â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“-ary tree of depth (distance from the root to the leaves) kğ‘˜kitalic_k oriented away from the root. An in-star/out-star is the orientation of an undirected star towards/away from its centre. We denote by Sk,â„“âˆ’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜â„“S^{-}_{k,\ell}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the (kâˆ’1)ğ‘˜1(k-1)( italic_k - 1 )-subdivision of the in-star with â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ leaves, and the directed paths from the leaves of Sk,â„“âˆ’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜â„“S^{-}_{k,\ell}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to its centre are referred to as the rays.
